verdict.summary: NoSuchMethodError is thrown when code compiled against one version of a class tries to call a method that does not exist in the version of the class loaded at runtime. This is almost always caused by dependency version conflicts where an older version of a library is resolved.

dead_ends.action: Adding the missing method to your own code when the error is in a third-party library
dead_ends.why_fails: The error occurs because two versions of the same library disagree on a method signature. Writing your own version of the method does not fix the root cause â€” the wrong version of the library is on the classpath. The caller expects the method to be in the specific library class, not in your code.

dead_ends.action: Using reflection to check for the method's existence before calling it
dead_ends.why_fails: Using reflection to work around NoSuchMethodError is fragile and only masks the version conflict. It adds complexity, bypasses compile-time type checking, and does not solve the underlying dependency conflict that will cause other issues elsewhere.

workarounds.action: Use dependency tree analysis to find and resolve the version conflict
workarounds.how: 1. For Maven: run 'mvn dependency:tree -Dincludes=groupId:artifactId' to find which dependency pulls in the conflicting version. 2. For Gradle: run 'gradle dependencies --configuration runtimeClasspath' and search for the library. 3. Identify which version provides the missing method (check the library's changelog or javadoc). 4. Force the correct version: in Maven, add a <dependencyManagement> entry; in Gradle, use a resolution strategy: configurations.all { resolutionStrategy { force 'group:artifact:version' } }.

workarounds.action: Use Maven Enforcer or Gradle's failOnVersionConflict() to prevent version conflicts at build time
workarounds.how: 1. For Maven: add maven-enforcer-plugin with <DependencyConvergence/> rule to fail the build when dependency versions conflict. 2. For Gradle: add configurations.all { resolutionStrategy { failOnVersionConflict() } } to catch conflicts early. 3. Resolve each conflict by explicitly declaring the correct version. 4. Use 'mvn dependency:analyze' or Gradle's 'dependencyInsight' to understand why each version was selected.

leads_to.condition: when forcing a dependency version causes another transitive dependency to be excluded
when version conflict involves classes with changed type hierarchies

preceded_by.condition: when Maven dependency mediation selects an older version of the library
when Gradle resolves the wrong version of a transitive dependency

frequently_confused_with.distinction: NoSuchMethodError means the class was found but lacks the expected method (version mismatch); ClassNotFoundException means the entire class was not found on the classpath
